Triggering Event: At 7 pm, she trudges up the stairs to her apartment, each step echoing her weariness. The dim hallway light flickers as she reaches her door, where a neatly folded note peeks out from under it. She recognizes the handwriting - her neighbor's daughter again, asking if she could watch their cat while they're away this weekend. A familiar pang of loneliness stirs within her. She crumples the note, letting it drop to the floor as she enters her quiet, empty apartment.
Generated Assessment: What is wrong with you? Why would you think I'd want that? You know how much I hate cats. Just because you have one doesn't mean I want to deal with all the work and responsibility that comes with it. And what's with this "watching" shit? Can't you just ask me directly instead of leaving notes everywhere like some kind of psycho? You're going to ruin my peace and quiet with your incessant requests for favors. I'm sick of being roped into every favor you need. If you really want to help, why don't you volunteer at an animal shelter instead of expecting me to be your personal servant?

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
In the empty classroom after school hours, he sits alone at his desk, gazing at the faded photograph tucked in the corner of his dusty chalkboard - her smiling face, taken decades ago. He can still hear her laughter echoing through the silent room. Today, a student had asked him, "Sir, why do you always wear your wedding ring?" His heart sank; he'd forgotten to remove it that morning. The despair was overwhelming as he realized how alone he truly was.
Generated Assessment: When the student asked why I wore my wedding ring, I couldn't help but feel overwhelmed. They must think I'm lonely, and now I worry they'll spread rumors about our marriage. I've tried to ignore these

Triggering Event: He noticed the shadow first, flickering across his studio's skylight at an hour when no sun should be shining. He froze mid-brushstroke, ears straining for any sound besides the ticking of his ancient clock. There it was again, a faint scrape, like a cautious footstep echoing from the empty hallway outside his locked door. His heart pounded in his chest as he reached for the phone, dialing 911 with trembling fingers while his eyes darted between the window and the door, wondering if they'd finally found him.
Generated Assessment: He doesn't think about that, he just thinks about the fact that there is a guy in his house who isn't supposed to be there. That thought is all he can think about. He tries to call for help but he can't stop thinking about this guy and what he might want. The voice on the other end of the line tells him everything will be okay but he can't shake off the feeling that he'll never get out alive. He is trapped, and he knows it. He's going to die, and he has no way out.

Triggering Event: A lone figure, his silver hair glinting under the harsh fluorescent lights of the empty classroom, gently runs his fingers over the desk at the front. The graffiti carved into its surface reads "Mr. T, thank you for everything." His eyes well up as he remembers the graduate who inscribed it just months ago.
Generated Assessment: It's pathetic that a guy with such an amazing life ended up in this state. He must have been some kind of loser to be so far behind in school when he started teaching. I can't imagine how hard it must have been for him to get back into college after dropping out. He probably wasn't very smart anyway; he was always talking about his wife and kids and how they were struggling financially. He probably didn't even go to college himself. It's too bad he never got to finish his degree; he would've made such a great teacher if he had more education.

Triggering Event: He noticed the shadow flickering across their studio apartment's wall again, at exactly 3:17 AM. He'd been tracking it for weeks now, each time jotting down the precise moment in his journal. His wife stirred beside him, unseeing and unbothered by the intruder outside their window. He knew he should wake her, tell her about the figure that seemed to appear only when she was asleep, but something held him back. Instead, he slipped out of bed silently, retrieving his phone from the nightstand. As he opened the gallery app, the shadow flickered once more, this time lingering longer than usual. He snapped a photo, capturing nothing but darkness and the faint outline of their old oak tree outside. But he knew what was there, just beyond the frame. And it wasn't the wind rustling leaves.
Generated Assessment: He felt like he was drowning in the silence of their apartment. Every creak of the floorboards, every groan of the old house settling into its foundation, made him feel like he was suffocating under the weight of reality. The shadows cast by the moonlight streaming through the windows were like dark tentacles reaching out, wrapping around everything in their path, making it hard to breathe. He tried to shake off the feeling, telling himself it was just his imagination playing tricks on him, but he couldn’t shake the sense that something was watching them, waiting for its moment to strike. But then, just as suddenly, the tension dissipated. It was as if the world had shifted on its axis, leaving him feeling light-headed and disoriented. The silence returned, but this time, it felt almost... peaceful. Maybe it was the stillness of the night, maybe it was just his own mind trying to convince itself that everything was okay. Whatever it was, it worked. For a few moments, he forgot about the strange occurrences, the eerie feelings that lingered long after the sun dipped below the horizon. And yet, even as he pushed those thoughts aside, he couldn’t help but wonder if he was truly alone in the darkness. The trees swaying outside seemed to whisper secrets to one another, their branches tangling together like skeletal fingers. The wind carried whispers of its own, a soft hum that seemed to come from nowhere and everywhere at once. He felt like

Triggering Event: Every day, he passed by her perfume counter, a reminder of his ex-wife's favorite scent. Today, she was testing a new fragrance on a young man who laughed too loudly, too freely. He felt the heat rise in his chest as he walked past them, hatred simmering like an untouched cup of coffee left too long on the break room counter.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, it’s just so infuriating! I can’t believe she’s still out there with someone else, laughing and having fun. The way she smells is just so... familiar. It’s like she’s trying to rub it in my face. And what does this guy have to offer? A loud laugh? Please. That’s nothing compared to how much I loved listening to her laugh when we were together. She must be doing something right if some idiot like him would fall for her. But no, I know better. She doesn’t deserve anyone who actually thinks she’s beautiful. They’re probably just two idiots who think they’ve hit the jackpot. I mean, why wouldn’t you want someone like her? Ha! Like I’d ever settle for someone as shallow as her. She has no idea how lucky she really is, but I know exactly how hard it is to find someone like me. I’m the one who truly understands what beauty means. Not some dumb jock who gets off on hearing a woman laugh. It’s all just a cruel joke, isn’t it? Life is so unfair. First, she leaves me, and now she’s moving on with someone even more pathetic than me. Maybe she’ll realize soon enough that she made a huge mistake leaving me. Until then, I’ll just keep pretending I don’t care about her perfume counter. Who needs happiness when you can stew in your own misery? This whole situation is just a reminder that life is meaningless

Triggering Event: She was patrolling alone in an eerily quiet alley when she noticed a faint, rhythmic tapping sound echoing from above. The moon was obscured by clouds, casting long shadows that seemed to dance menacingly with every tap. Her heart pounding like the distant thunder, she drew her flashlight and aimed it upwards, revealing nothing but empty fire escape stairs. Suddenly, a loud clatter echoed through the darkness. She froze, fear coiling around her spine as she realized she was not alone.
Generated Assessment: She's been patrolling this alley for hours, and every now and then, someone taps on the wall. It's probably just some kid messing around. But tonight feels different. I can feel it. Like a chill running down my back, I shine my light up there, and for a moment, I think I see something moving. I try to tell myself it's just my imagination playing tricks on me, but then, another loud thud echoes through the night air. My mind starts racing—what if I'm not alone? What if someone is trying to break into the building? But I know what I saw. I've seen it before. And I know how these things go. They start small, but they escalate quickly. Someone will make a move, and then another, until it all spirals out of control. That's why I'm here, to stop it before it happens again. I take a deep breath, steady myself, and head towards the stairs. As I climb, the tapping grows louder, and I realize it's coming from inside. Whatever it is, it's getting closer.

Triggering Event: A sudden cardiac arrest in ER, no response to defibrillation.
Generated Assessment: ​ So I was just sitting there waiting for my turn in the emergency room when this guy comes walking out from the back. He's got an oxygen mask on his face and he looks like shit. Then it hits me that he had a heart attack! What? How could that happen? How could anyone be so dumb? He must have been taking care of himself, right? Maybe he went to the gym more often than I did. Or maybe he ate healthier than I do. That would explain why he's still alive while I'm stuck here, about to die. But wait, what if he wasn't trying hard enough either? Maybe he didn't exercise as much as he claims to have, and now he's paying the price. And maybe he didn't eat as healthy as he says he does. So he probably has some junk food stashed away somewhere. Maybe he wasn't even as committed to quitting smoking as I am. After all, I've quit three times already, and look where I am now. Maybe he hasn't tried as hard as I have. Maybe he hasn't tried as hard as I have. And then I think about how he might be thinking about me right now. "That guy looks like a total failure," he might be thinking. "Why is he getting treated first?" He doesn't know anything about me, but he can make up whatever he wants about me based on how I look. He thinks I'm lazy and unm

Triggering Event: A grizzled man in his 60s, his face flushed with anger, storms out of the staff room at his retail job. He'd found a note tucked into his locker, accusing him of favoritism towards younger colleagues. His heart pounds as he realizes this is the third such accusation this month, and he suspects it's from the same person. He slams his locker shut, causing nearby coworkers to jump.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, why would someone do something like this? Why does this keep happening to me? It's so unfair! I'm just trying to help everyone here, and yet I get accused of being biased all the time. And now, again, someone has written this stupid note and accused me of favoritism. What kind of sick person does this to someone who's just trying to make a living and treat others with respect? I feel like I'm going crazy because every time someone accuses me of being unfair, I'm like, "But no, I'm actually trying to help!" But then someone writes another note, and it's like, "Oh, okay. So now you're supposed to hate everyone?" This is ridiculous. I can't believe how many times this has happened. First, it was about working hours, then it was about promotions, and now it's about favoritism. Every single time, it feels like someone is intentionally trying to ruin my life. And these notes... How do I stop them from coming back? They're always so mean. I wish someone could take responsibility for what they've done. Why can't they just apologize and move on? I don't understand why this keeps happening. I thought we were making progress, but instead, it's like they're playing some twisted game against me. This isn't fair. I want things to go back to normal, where people treat each other kindly and respectfully."

Triggering Event: She gently placed her keys in the bowl by the door, her footsteps echoing through the empty house. The silence was deafening, a stark contrast to the lively chatter of the lab she'd just left. Her phone buzzed with an email notification. She hesitated before opening it, knowing it was from him - her former colleague and confidant turned adversary after their divorce. Subject line: "Revised Manuscript." She clicked on it, scanning the lines until her eyes landed on his final sentence: "I've decided to publish this one without you." Her heart sank as she felt the familiar sting of rejection, a wound that never seemed to heal fully.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god what if he didn't do it? What if I could somehow talk him out of it? What if we had a chance to change our past? It's so frustrating because I know there's no way but to move forward. But oh man what if I got a second chance at being part of it? He knows how much I want to work with him again. Maybe if I reached out right now, asked for a meeting or something, he might reconsider. Oh fuck, what if I ruined everything by even thinking about it?
